title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement felipelfv98@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to structest
text: Thank considering contributing structest! package implements statistical tests VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) rejecting structural interpretation latent factor model. Contributions improve package welcome.

title: Contributing to structest
text: encounter bug suggestion, please open issue GitHub. reporting bug: Provide clear descriptive title. Include minimal reproducible example demonstrating problem. Describe expected behaviour actually happened. Include R version sessionInfo() output relevant.

title: Contributing to structest
text: Fork repository GitHub. Clone fork local machine. Install development dependencies. Make sure package passes checks start.
code: git clone https://github.com/your-username/structest.git cd structest install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_deps() devtools::check() devtools::test()

title: Contributing to structest
text: Always create new branch work.

title: Contributing to structest
text: Make changes codebase. Write tests changes applicable. use testthat unit tests. use roxygen2 Markdown syntax documentation. Edit .R source files, .Rd files directly. Run devtools::document() changing roxygen comments. Run devtools::test() ensure changes break existing functionality.

title: Contributing to structest
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source .R file (generated .Rd file).

title: Contributing to structest
text: Push changes fork. Open pull request GitHub main branch. Provide clear descriptive title pull request. Describe changes made necessary. Reference related issues (e.g., Fixes #issue-number). Ensure tests pass merge conflicts.

title: Contributing to structest
text: use LLMs (e.g., ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot) assist contributions. However, use LLM generate code, please: Provide clear explanation choices made code. able justify code . transparent — LLM wrote entirety contribution, say pull request. Review understand generated code submitting. responsible correctness contribution.

title: Contributing to structest
text: Please note structest project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Factor analysis one widely used methods social behavioural sciences. single latent factor fits covariance among set observed indicators, researchers often treat latent variable causally relevant quantity subsequent analyses. practice implicitly assumes structural interpretation latent factor model: latent variable , rather individual indicators, causally efficacious. measurement model fits well guarantee structural interpretation correct. indicators direct causal effects outcome, even though covariance structure perfectly consistent single latent factor. structural interpretation wrong, causal conclusions treating latent variable cause may misleading. VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) showed structural interpretation imposes testable empirical constraints. structest package implements two statistical tests—\(T_0\) \(T_1\)—can reject constraints, providing researchers principled way evaluate whether structural interpretation tenable.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Consider reflective latent factor model \(d\) indicators (Equation 1 paper). standardisation \(\eta\) mean zero unit variance, centred indicator : \[ X_i = \lambda_i\,\eta + \varepsilon_i, \qquad = 1, \ldots, d \tag{1} \] \(\eta\) latent variable, \(\lambda_i\) reliabilities, \(\varepsilon_i\) mean-zero random errors independent \(\eta\) . (Following paper, use term “reliabilities” \(\lambda_i\); mainstream psychometrics commonly known factor loadings.) structural interpretation, latent variable \(\eta\) causally relevant quantity: indicators \((X_1, \ldots, X_d)\) causal effects anything subsequent, affected antecedents \(\eta\). strong assumption—basic measurement model (1) fitting well imply . external variable \(Z\) structural latent factor model holds, \(Z\) must independent \((X_1, \ldots, X_d)\) conditional \(\eta\). yields following testable constraint: Theorem 1 (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022). Suppose \(Z\) independent \((X_1, \ldots, X_d)\) conditional \(\eta\) basic latent factor model Equation (1) holds. \(\) \(j\), values \(z\) \(z^*\), must \[ \lambda_i \bigl\{E(X_j \mid Z=z) - E(X_j \mid Z=z^*)\bigr\} = \lambda_j \bigl\{E(X_i \mid Z=z) - E(X_i \mid Z=z^*)\bigr\}. \] Equivalently, dividing reliabilities: \[ \frac{E(X_j \mid Z = z) - E(X_j \mid Z = z^*)}{\lambda_j} = \frac{E(X_i \mid Z = z) - E(X_i \mid Z = z^*)}{\lambda_i}, \qquad \forall\; , j. \] mean differences scaled reliabilities must constant across indicators. Note Theorem 1 completely general: \(Z\) can continuous discrete, identity holds external variable. Appendix paper generalises result allow conditioning covariates \(C\) multivariate latent variables \(\eta\) (provided number indicators exceeds dimension \(\eta\)). However, \(T_0\) \(T_1\) tests implemented require \(Z\) discrete finite number levels, moment conditions parameterised using category indicators \((z = w)\). practice, continuous \(Z\) must therefore discretised (e.g., quantile groups) applying tests. \(T_0\) \(T_1\) tests formalise constraint Theorem 1 using distance metric statistics generalised method moments (GMM) framework (Newey & McFadden, 1994). moment conditions restrictions conditional means \(E(X_i \mid Z = z_j)\): null, residuals (observed minus predicted model) average zero. GMM stacks residuals vector measures far sample average deviates zero using variance-weighted quadratic form; resulting statistic asymptotically \(\chi^2\)-distributed null.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: \(T_0\) test (Section 3.2 paper) requires pre-estimated reliabilities \(\hat\lambda_i\) (see Estimating Reliabilities ). Consider discrete \(Z\) categories \(\{1, \ldots, p\}\). Define \(\gamma_i = E(X_i \mid Z = 1)\) \(\beta_w = E(X_1 \mid Z = w) - E(X_1 \mid Z = 1)\). null hypothesis, conditional expectations follow restricted model (Equation 2 paper): \[ E(X_i \mid Z = z) = \gamma_i + \frac{\lambda_i}{\lambda_1} \sum_{w=2}^{p} \beta_w\, (z = w) \tag{2} \] \(= 1, \ldots, d\), reliabilities \(\lambda_i\) treated known (plugged estimation step). model \(d + p - 1\) free parameters (\(\gamma_1, \ldots, \gamma_d\) \(\beta_2, \ldots, \beta_p\), \(\beta_1 = 0\) reference level).

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: null, model Equation (2) implies indicator \(\) Z-level \(j\), \(E[X_i \mid Z = z_j] - \gamma_i - (\lambda_i/\lambda_1)\sum\beta_w (z_j = w) = 0\). GMM constructs moment conditions restrictions defining, observation \(k\), residual \(X_{ik}\) minus predicted value model. Let \(U_k\) \((d \times p)\)-dimensional column vector elements \[ (Z_k = z_j)\!\left(X_{ik} - \gamma_i   - \frac{\lambda_i}{\lambda_1}\sum_{w=2}^{p}\beta_w\,(z_j = w)\right) \] \(z_j = 1, \ldots, p\) \(= 1, \ldots, d\). model correctly specified, \(E[U_k] = 0\); test measures far sample average \(\bar U = N^{-1}\sum_k U_k\) deviates zero. distance metric statistic \[ T_0 = N\,\bar U^\top\, \Sigma^{-1}\, \bar U, \] \(\Sigma\) empirical covariance matrix \(U_k\) adjusting uncertainty estimated reliabilities (see ). quadratic form measures squared distance \(\bar U\) zero, weighted \(\Sigma^{-1}\) standardise moment condition variance account correlations . minimum \(T_0\) free parameters converges \(\chi^2\) distribution \((d - 1)(p - 1)\) degrees freedom null (theorem 9.2 Newey & McFadden, 1994).

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: practice reliabilities \(\lambda_i\) unknown replaced estimates \(\hat\lambda_i\). account additional uncertainty (p. 2041 paper), covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) \(T_0\) computed adjusted moment contributions \[ U_k^* = U_k - \left(\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}   \frac{\partial U_k}{\partial \lambda}\right) \left(\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}   \frac{\partial V_k}{\partial \lambda}\right)^{\!-1} V_k, \] \(\lambda = (\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_d)\) \(V_k\) \(d\)-dimensional vector reliability estimating equations elements \[ V_{ik} = \sum_{\substack{j=1 \\ j \neq }}^{d} \lambda_j \left\{\!\left(X_i - \bar X_i\right)\! \left(X_j - \bar X_j\right) - \lambda_i\lambda_j\right\}. \] empirical covariance \(U_k^*\) (rather \(U_k\)) used \(\Sigma\), yielding test statistic remains \(\chi^2_{(d-1)(p-1)}\) null. use: \(d \geq 3\) indicators \(p \geq 2\) levels \(Z\).

what: Example: data consistent with the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: data generated structural model, test statistic small \(p\)-value large—fail reject \(H_0\).
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5  # Simulate under the structural model z <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)                        # binary auxiliary variable eta <- 1 + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n)                 # latent factor affected by Z lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7)         # reliabilities X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- 2 + lambda[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # T0 test (should NOT reject) result_t0 <- test_t0(X, z); (result_t0) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 6.075, df = 4, p-value = 0.1936 #> n = 5000, d = 5 indicators, p = 2 Z-levels

what: Example: data violating the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Now consider data \(Z\) direct effects indicator proportional reliabilities, act \(\eta\): test statistic large \(p\)-value small, correctly rejecting structural interpretation. can inspect full output summary():
code: set.seed(12345) eta <- rnorm(n)                                # Z does not affect eta X_bad <- cbind(   2 + 1.0 * eta + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   3 + 0.8 * eta + 2.0 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.6 * eta - 0.3 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   2 + 0.9 * eta + 0.4 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.7 * eta + 0.8 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3) )  # T0 test (should reject) result_t0_bad <- test_t0(X_bad, z); (result_t0_bad) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #> statistic = 2226, df = 4, p-value = < 2.2e-16 #> n = 5000, d = 5 indicators, p = 2 Z-levels summary(result_t0_bad) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #>  #> Test statistic:  2226  #> Degrees of freedom:  4  #> P-value:  < 2.2e-16  #>  #> Sample size:  5000  #> Indicators (d):  5  #> Z-levels (p):  2  #> Convergence code:  1  #>  #> Parameter estimates: #>   gamma (intercepts): #>     X1     X2     X3     X4     X5  #> 1.7006 2.7836 0.8274 1.7447 0.7968  #>   beta (Z effects): #>   z=0   z=1  #> 0.000 1.728  #>   lambda (reliabilities): #> [1] 1.0099 1.0213 0.4555 0.9002 0.8222

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: \(T_1\) test (Section 3.3 paper) avoids estimating reliabilities entirely, relying instead equivalent reformulation Theorem 1: Theorem 2 (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022). basic latent factor model Equation (1), discrete \(Z\) following equivalent: \(\) \(j\), values \(z\) \(z^*\), \(\lambda_i\{E(X_j \mid Z = z) - E(X_j \mid Z = z^*)\} = \lambda_j\{E(X_i \mid Z = z) - E(X_i \mid Z = z^*)\}\). \(\) values \(z\), \(z^*\), \(E(X_i \mid Z = z) - E(X_i \mid Z = z^*) = \alpha_i\,\beta_z\) parameters \(\alpha_i\), \(\beta_z\). Condition 2 says \(d \times (p-1)\) matrix mean differences \(\Delta_{ij} = E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) - E(X_i \mid Z = z_1)\) rank \(\leq 1\), since factors \(\mathbf{\alpha}\,\mathbf{\beta}^\top\). Rank \(\leq 1\) means every column \(\Delta\) scalar multiple every column: pattern mean differences across indicators matter Z-levels compare, overall magnitude changes. can tested without knowing \(\lambda_i\). null, conditional expectations satisfy (Equation 3 paper): \[ E(X_i \mid Z = z) = \gamma_i + \sum_{w=2}^{p} \alpha_i\,\beta_w\,(z = w) \tag{3} \] \(= 1, \ldots, d\), \(\alpha_1 = 1\) identification (product \(\alpha_i \beta_z\) invariant rescaling \(\alpha_i/\tau\), \(\beta_z \tau\)) \(\beta_1 = 0\) reference level. model \(2d + p - 2\) free parameters (\(d\) intercepts \(\gamma_i\), \(d - 1\) free \(\alpha_i\)’s, \(p - 1\) free \(\beta_w\)’s).

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: \(T_0\), moment conditions constructed residuals: observed minus predicted null model. Let \(U_k\) \((d \times p)\)-dimensional column vector elements \[ (Z_k = z_j)\!\left(X_{ik} - \gamma_i - \alpha_i\,\beta_w\right) \] \(z_j = 1, \ldots, p\) \(= 1, \ldots, d\), \(\beta_w = \beta_{z_j}\). Equation (3), \(E[U_k] = 0\); test measures far \(\bar U = N^{-1}\sum_k U_k\) deviates . distance metric statistic \[ T_1 = N\!\left(\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N} U_k^{\!\top}\right) \Sigma^{-1} \left(\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N} U_k\right), \] \(\Sigma\) empirical covariance matrix \(U_k\). Unlike \(T_0\), variance adjustment needed since \(T_1\) use estimated reliabilities. minimum \(T_1\) free parameters converges \(\chi^2\) distribution \[ d \times p - (2d + p - 2) = (d - 1)(p - 2) \] degrees freedom null. \(T_1\) depend reliability estimates, sensitive misspecification error covariance structure (e.g., correlated heteroscedastic \(\varepsilon_i\)). use: \(d \geq 2\) indicators \(p \geq 3\) levels \(Z\). Preferred \(T_0\) rely error-structure assumptions needed reliability estimation.

what: Example: data consistent with the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: , test reject—consistent data generated structural model.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 4  # Simulate under the structural model with a 4-level Z z <- sample(0:3, n, replace = TRUE) eta <- 1 + 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.7 * (z == 2) + 1.2 * (z == 3) + rnorm(n) lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9) X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- 2 + lambda[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # T1 test (should NOT reject) result_t1 <- test_t1(X, z); (result_t1) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 3.017, df = 6, p-value = 0.8068 #> n = 5000, d = 4 indicators, p = 4 Z-levels

what: Example: data violating the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: structural interpretation rejected, expected.
code: set.seed(12345) eta <- rnorm(n) X_bad <- cbind(   2 + 1.0 * eta + 0.5 * (z == 1) + 0.3 * (z == 2) + 0.4 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   3 + 0.8 * eta + 2.0 * (z == 1) + 0.1 * (z == 2) + 3.0 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.6 * eta - 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.8 * (z == 2) - 0.5 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   2 + 0.9 * eta + 0.4 * (z == 1) + 0.6 * (z == 2) + 0.3 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3) )  # T1 test (should reject) result_t1_bad <- test_t1(X_bad, z); (result_t1_bad) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #> statistic = 1400, df = 6, p-value = < 2.2e-16 #> n = 5000, d = 4 indicators, p = 4 Z-levels summary(result_t1_bad) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #>  #> Test statistic:  1400  #> Degrees of freedom:  6  #> P-value:  < 2.2e-16  #>  #> Sample size:  5000  #> Indicators (d):  4  #> Z-levels (p):  4  #> Convergence code:  1  #>  #> Parameter estimates: #>   gamma (intercepts): #>     X1     X2     X3     X4  #> 2.0872 3.0878 1.0656 2.1163  #>   alpha: #>      X1      X2      X3      X4  #>  1.0000  7.7155 -1.5389  0.6065  #>   beta (Z effects): #>     z=0     z=1     z=2     z=3  #>  0.0000  0.2378 -0.0676  0.3796

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: estimate_reliability() function estimates reliabilities \(\lambda_i\) following Section 3.1 paper. model (1) \(\text{Var}(\eta) = 1\) independent errors, -diagonal covariances factor \[ \text{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \lambda_i\,\lambda_j, \qquad \neq j. \] Consistent estimators \(\hat\lambda_i\) obtained solving \(d\) unbiased estimating equations (one per indicator): \[ \sum_{\substack{j=1 \\ j \neq }}^{d} \frac{\lambda_j}{N} \sum_{k=1}^{N}\left(X_{ik} - \bar X_i\right) \left(X_{jk} - \bar X_j\right) - \lambda_i\lambda_j = 0, \qquad = 1, \ldots, d. \] Taking logs \(\text{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \lambda_i\lambda_j\) gives \(\log E(C_{ij}) = \log\lambda_i + \log\lambda_j\), linear model log-reliabilities. Writing \(\Lambda_s = \log\lambda_s\): \[ \log E\!\left(C_{ij}\right) = \sum_{s=1}^{d} \Lambda_s\, (s \\{, j\}) \] \(C_{ij}\) sample covariance \(X_i\) \(X_j\), \((\cdot)\) indicator function. solutions readily obtained exponentiated coefficients quasi-Poisson GLM log link, using \(d(d-1)/2\) pairwise covariances response \(d\)-column binary design matrix indicating indicators involved pair. function called internally test_t0(), can use directly need reliability estimates purposes.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5 eta <- rnorm(n) lambda_true <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7) X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- lambda_true[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  rel <- estimate_reliability(X)  # Compare estimated vs true data.frame(   true = lambda_true,   estimated = round(rel$lambda, 3) ) #>   true estimated #> 1  1.0     0.974 #> 2  0.8     0.808 #> 3  0.6     0.594 #> 4  0.9     0.898 #> 5  0.7     0.695

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Guidance: \(T_1\) generally preferred depend error-structure assumptions needed estimate reliabilities (e.g., independent, homoscedastic errors). \(T_0\) necessary 2 levels \(Z\) available, since \(T_1\) requires \(p \geq 3\). tests applicable (\(d \geq 3\), \(p \geq 3\)), running provides useful sensitivity check. Agreement strengthens conclusion; disagreement may signal misspecification error distribution (affects \(T_0\) \(T_1\)).

what: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: R package implementing statistical tests : VanderWeele, T. J. & Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054. doi:10.1111/rssb.12555

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: Factor analysis routinely used assess whether single univariate latent variable explains covariance among set observed indicators. one-factor model fits adequately, researchers often treat latent variable causally relevant quantity subsequent analyses. practice implicitly assumes structural interpretation latent factor model: latent variable, rather individual indicators, causally efficacious. However, measurement model fitting well imply structural interpretation correct. individual indicators separate causal effects outcomes, even though covariance structure consistent single latent factor (see Figures 2 3 paper). VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) show structural interpretation empirically testable implications. Specifically, structural latent factor model, association external variable Z indicator X_i, scaled reliability X_i, must across indicators (Theorem 1). package implements two statistical tests proposed paper: T0: statistical test dependent reliability estimates (Section 3.2) T1: statistical test independent reliability estimates (Section 3.3) Note terminology: Following paper, package refers coefficients lambda_i “reliabilities.” mainstream psychometrics commonly known factor loadings.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: Please note structest project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: VanderWeele, T. J. & Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054. doi:10.1111/rssb.12555

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: Estimates reliability coefficients \(\lambda_i\) indicator univariate latent factor model, using pairwise covariances quasi-Poisson GLM log link.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: list components: lambda numeric vector length d estimated reliabilities. glm_fit fitted glm object. V_k matrix (n x d) per-subject estimating function contributions reliability parameters (used internally test_t0). U_pairs matrix (n x choose(d,2)) pairwise estimating function contributions (used internally test_t0). pairs matrix (choose(d,2) x 2) indicator index pairs. Xc matrix (n x d) mean-centred indicators.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: structural model \(X_i = \mu_i + \lambda_i \eta + \varepsilon_i\), \(\mathrm{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \lambda_i \lambda_j\). log pairwise covariance modelled linear combination \(\log(\lambda_i)\), yielding quasi-Poisson GLM.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
code: # Simulate data from a one-factor model set.seed(42) n <- 1000 eta <- rnorm(n) lambda_true <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6) X <- cbind(   lambda_true[1] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   lambda_true[2] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   lambda_true[3] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) )  rel <- estimate_reliability(X) rel$lambda #> [1] 1.0221319 0.7752837 0.6143667  # Ratios lambda_i / lambda_1 should be close to truth rel$lambda / rel$lambda[1] #> [1] 1.0000000 0.7584967 0.6010640  set.seed(12345) n <- 1000 eta <- rnorm(n) lambda_true <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6) X <- cbind(   lambda_true[1] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   lambda_true[2] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   lambda_true[3] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) )  rel <- estimate_reliability(X) rel$lambda #> [1] 1.0258103 0.7859982 0.5831385  # Ratios lambda_i / lambda_1 should be close to truth rel$lambda / rel$lambda[1] #> [1] 1.0000000 0.7662218 0.5684662

what: Print method for structest objects — print.structest

what: structest: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model — structest-package
title: structest: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model — structest-package
text: Implements two statistical tests VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) reject structural interpretation univariate latent factor model.

title: structest: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model — structest-package
text: test_t0 Reliability-dependent test (Section 3.2). Requires d >= 3 indicators p >= 2 Z-levels. test_t1 Reliability-independent test (Section 3.3). Requires d >= 2 indicators p >= 3 Z-levels. estimate_reliability Estimate reliability coefficients via quasi-Poisson GLM (Section 3.1).

title: structest: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model — structest-package
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054.

title: structest: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model — structest-package
text: Maintainer: Felipe Fontana Vieira felipelfv98@gmail.com

what: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: Tests whether structural interpretation univariate latent factor model can rejected, using estimated reliability coefficients. variance estimating equations adjusted uncertainty reliability estimates (see paper, p. 2041).

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
code: test_t0(X, z, na.rm = TRUE, max_iter = 1000L, verbose = FALSE)

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. z numeric vector factor length n encoding discrete auxiliary variable. Must least 2 distinct levels. z continuous, discretise (e.g., quantile groups) use. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed. max_iter integer; maximum iterations nlm. verbose logical; TRUE, print progress information.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: object class c("structest_t0", "structest", "htest") containing: statistic T0 test statistic. parameter degrees freedom, \((d-1)(p-1)\). p.value p-value chi-squared distribution. method description test. data.name name data objects. estimates list gamma (intercepts), beta (Z effects), lambda (reliabilities). n_obs number observations used. d number indicators. p number Z-levels. convergence convergence code nlm. optim_details full output nlm.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: structural model, \(E[X_i | Z = z_j] = \gamma_i + (\lambda_i / \lambda_1) \beta_j\). gives \(d \times p\) moment conditions \(d + p - 1\) free parameters (\(\gamma_1, \ldots, \gamma_d\) \(\beta_2, \ldots, \beta_p\) \(\beta_1 = 0\)), yielding \((d-1)(p-1)\) degrees freedom. variance estimating equations adjusted uncertainty reliability estimates \(\lambda_i\) (see paper, p. 2041). Consistent generalised methods moments estimators (Newey & McFadden, 1994) obtained minimising resulting distance metric statistic.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 1000 z <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) eta <- 1 + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n) lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6) X <- cbind(   2 + lambda[1] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   3 + lambda[2] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   1 + lambda[3] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) )  result <- test_t0(X, z) result #>  #> 	 T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 6.452, df = 2, p-value = 0.03971 #> n = 1000, d = 3 indicators, p = 2 Z-levels #>

what: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: Tests whether structural interpretation univariate latent factor model can rejected, without requiring estimation reliability coefficients.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
code: test_t1(X, z, na.rm = TRUE, max_iter = 1000L, tol = 1e-25, verbose = FALSE)

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 2. z numeric vector factor length n encoding discrete auxiliary variable. Must least 3 distinct levels. z continuous, discretise (e.g., quantile groups) use. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed. max_iter integer; maximum iterations nlm. tol numeric; convergence tolerance alternating LS initializer. verbose logical; TRUE, print progress information.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: object class c("structest_t1", "structest", "htest") containing: statistic T1 test statistic. parameter degrees freedom, \((d-1)(p-2)\). p.value p-value chi-squared distribution. method description test. data.name name data objects. estimates list gamma (\(\gamma_i\)), alpha (\(\alpha_i\), \(\alpha_1 = 1\)), beta (\(\beta_j\), \(\beta_1 = 0\)). n_obs number observations used. d number indicators. p number Z-levels. convergence convergence code nlm. optim_details full output nlm.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: structural model \(X_i = \mu_i + \lambda_i \eta + \varepsilon_i\), conditional expectations satisfy $$E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) = \gamma_i + \alpha_i \beta_j$$ \(\gamma_i\) intercepts absorbing reference-level means, \(\alpha_i\) parameters (\(\alpha_1 = 1\) identification), \(\beta_j\) parameters (\(\beta_1 = 0\) reference level). gives \(d \times p\) moment conditions: $$E[(Z = z_j)(X_i - \gamma_i - \alpha_i \beta_j)] = 0$$ \(2d + p - 2\) free parameters (\(d\) intercepts, \(d - 1\) alphas, \(p - 1\) betas), yielding \(dp - (2d + p - 2) = (d-1)(p-2)\) degrees freedom. test checks whether mean-difference matrix \(\Delta_{ij} = E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) - E(X_i \mid Z = z_1)\) rank \(\le 1\), testable implication structural model (Theorem 2 paper). Consistent generalised methods moments estimators (Newey & McFadden, 1994) obtained minimising distance metric statistic. procedure uses two-step estimation obtain stable initial estimates, minimises criterion weight matrix recomputed parameter value. test statistic asymptotically \(\chi^2_{(d-1)(p-2)}\) null.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 1000 z <- sample(0:2, n, replace = TRUE) eta <- 1 + 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.7 * (z == 2) + rnorm(n) lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6) X <- cbind(   2 + lambda[1] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   3 + lambda[2] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5),   1 + lambda[3] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) )  result <- test_t1(X, z) result #>  #> 	 T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 0.4784, df = 2, p-value = 0.7872 #> n = 1000, d = 3 indicators, p = 3 Z-levels #>

title: structest 0.1.0
text: Initial release. Implements test_t0(): reliability-dependent test structural interpretation (Section 3.2 VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022). Implements test_t1(): reliability-independent test structural interpretation (Section 3.3 VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022). Implements estimate_reliability(): estimation reliability coefficients via quasi-Poisson GLM pairwise covariances (Section 3.1).
